questions.text: 24-Year-old primigravida presented to emergency with show and abdominal pain. She was immediately admitted to the labour room for vaginal delivery. On PV examination, the JR post found the fetus to be in occipito posterior position. What should be the engaging diameter of the head?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Occipitofrontal - 11.5 cm In the given question, the engaging diameter for occipitoposterior position is – occipitofrontal - 11.5 cm , as the head in the OP position is deflexed Because of the deflexion, engagement is delayed.

Highyeild:

Mento-vertical: 14 cm Sub-mento-vertical: 11.5 cm Occipito-frontal: 11.5 cm Sub-occipito-frontal: 10.5 cm Sub-occipito-bregmatic: 9.5 cm Sub-mento-bregmatic: 9.5 cm Bi-mastoid: 7.5 cm Bi-temporal: 8 cm Bi-parietal: 9.5 cm

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Suboccipitobregmatic - seen when there is marked flexion of the head. Option: B. Mentovertical - it occurs in partial extension. Option: C. Submentobregmatic - it occurs in complete extension.

Extraedge:

The most common position of the fetus: LOT The most common position during labour: LOT The most common position occipitoanterior position: LOA The most common occipitoposterior position: ROP

questions.text: A 28-Year-old female at 39 weeks of POG with G2P1 was admitted to the labour room with abdominal pain. On monitoring, there were 3 contractions/10 mins of 35 seconds duration. 10 hours later, on a PV examination, the cervix is fully dilated, and 70% effaced. Even 1 hour after full dilatation there is no progression of labor. The head-on earlier PV examination was found to be in occipito posterior position and still, there is no change in the position. During history taking, the patient told that the previous delivery was a normal vaginal delivery. What would be the appropriate management in this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Manual rotation followed by forceps extraction

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventouse application and extraction The given clinical scenario points towards a persistent occipitoposterior position as the head does not rotate even after good uterine contractions and full dilatation of the cervix. As there is a history of previous NVD, hence the pelvis is adequate, so the ventouse can be applied for rotation of the head and simultaneous delivery.

Highyeild:

The occipitoposterior position is mostly idiopathic. Most common causes: Anthropoid and android pelvis. Most common in nulliparous females. In 90% of cases, normal delivery occurs as the head moves through 3/8th of a circle. Best management: Wait & watch. Android pelvis: DTA common, go for C-section .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. C section is required in cases of contraindication of normal vaginal delivery . As in this patient, there is no such condition mentioned, so there is no need for a C-section. Option: B. Manual rotation followed by forceps extraction can be done but ventouse being less traumatic is favoured and is a better answer than this. Option: D. Craniotomy is done in cases of dead fetuses.

Extraedge:

Direct occipitoposterior position is more common in the anthropoid pelvis - face to pubis delivery. In the other pelvis - deep sacral arrest, do C-section.

questions.text: A 22-Year-old primigravida female with onset of labour pain. On PV examination: An elongated bag of the membrane is seen which can rupture.The posterior fontanel is felt near the right sacroiliac joint. A diagnosis of occipito-posterior position was made. What should be the appropriate step in the management of this female?

options.label: C
options.text: Use a vacuum for the rotation of the head

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wait and watch In the given scenario, a primigravida with occipito posterior, the appropriate management will be to wait and watch. Because in most circumstances (90%) – internal rotation of the head takes place by 3/8 of a circle anteriorly to lie behind the pubic symphysis and shoulder by 2/8 of a circle to reduce torsion on the neck.

Highyeild:

The occipitoposterior position is mostly idiopathic. Most common causes: Anthropoid and android pelvis. Most common in nulliparous females. In 90% of cases, normal delivery occurs as the head moves through 3/8th of a circle. Best management: Wait & watch. Android pelvis: DTA common, go for C-section.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Immediate C-section is to be done in cases of non-rotation or malrotation (10%). – like incomplete forward rotation by 1/8 of a circle which results in a deep transverse arrest. Option: C. As spontaneous rotation can occur, hence there is no need for the vacuum to rotate the head of the fetus.

Extraedge:

Direct occipitoposterior position is more common in the anthropoid pelvis - face to pubis delivery. In the other pelvis - deep sacral arrest, do C-section.

questions.text: A 23-Year-old woman comes to you with 2 uterine contractions in 10 mins. On per abdomen examination, you find sub-umbilical flattening. On per vaginal examination, you feel the anterior fontanelle more prominently, sagittal sutures in the right oblique diameter. Her pelvis seems adequate for baby size. You augment her with an oxytocin drip. After about 2 hrs you find her cervix to be fully dilated with 4 uterine contractions per 10 mins but the deflexed head is persistent with no progression in the station of the head which is at the ischial spine. What will you do now?

options.label: A
options.text: No active intervention, allow for spontaneous labour

questions.explanation:
Solution:

LSCS If there is failure to progress (arrest) in spite of good uterine contractions for about 1/2–1 hour after full dilatation of the cervix , interference is indicated. The patient is in persistent occipito-posterior presentation with a station at 0. Therefore LSCS is indicated in her.

questions.text: A 24-Year-old primigravid woman, at term, has been in labour for 16 hours and has been dilated to 9 cm for 3 hours. The fetal vertex is in the right occiput posterior position, at +1 station, and moulded. There have been mild late decelerations for the past 30 minutes. Twenty minutes ago, the fetal scalp pH was 7.27; it is now 7.20. How will you manage her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low transverse cesarean section A woman who has been dilated 9 cm for 3 hours is experiencing a second arrest of dilation in labour. The deteriorating fetal condition (as evidenced, eg by late decelerations and falling scalp pH) dictates immediate delivery.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: External version is also not helpful for a woman who is in ongoing labour pains. Option B: A forceps rotation would be inappropriate because the cervix is not fully dilated . The cesarean section would be the safest and most expeditious method. Option D: Classic cesarean section is rarely used now because of greater blood loss and a higher incidence in subsequent pregnancies of rupture of the scar prior to labour. The best procedure would be a low transverse cesarean section.

questions.text: A 26-Year-old woman comes to you in 10 cm dilatation. You feel the anterior fontanelle more prominently, sagittal sutures in the transverse diameter, station +2. On further examination you find the pelvis to be adequate. By your assessment, the EFW is 2.5 kg. How will you manage this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Apply ventouse in the 2nd stage of labour to facilitate rotation of the head

options.label: D
options.text: Apply forceps in the 2nd stage to cut short the stage

questions.correct_answer: C. Apply ventouse in the 2nd stage of labour to facilitate rotation of the head
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Apply ventouse in the 2nd stage of labour to facilitate rotation of the head The patient is in deep transverse arrest (anterior fontanelle more prominently, sagittal sutures in the transverse diameter). The patient has a roomy pelvis and the baby's weight is average. The cervix is completely dilated.

Highyeild:

In DTA: Vaginal delivery is found to be unsafe (big baby and or inadequate pelvis): Cesarean section. If vaginal delivery is found safe (any of the methods may be employed): Ventouse— Excessive traction force should not be used. Manual rotation and application of forceps. Forceps rotation and delivery with Kielland in the hands of an expert. Operative vaginal delivery for DTA should only be performed by a skilled obstetrician. Otherwise, cesarean delivery is always preferred.

questions.text: A 30-Year-old G2P1 female presented at 41 weeks of POG with labour pain. PV findings are given below: The posterior fontanel is difficult to palpate and the anterior fontanel is palpated on the left side anteriorly, head is at -1 station, membranes intact. After a few hours, the cervix is fully dilated with 80% effaced, and the head is engaged and below the ischial spine(+2). The anterior fontanel is palpated just below the pubis and the occiput is near the sacral promontory. What is the management of choice for this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Manual rotation followed by delivery of the head

options.label: C
options.text: Ventouse or forceps application followed by face-to-pubis delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Wait and watch for spontaneous rotation.

questions.correct_answer: C. Ventouse or forceps application followed by face-to-pubis delivery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ventouse or forceps application followed by face-to-pubis delivery Ventouse or forceps application followed by face-to-pubis delivery. In the given clinical scenario, the fetus which was in the right occipitoposterior position and then rotated 1/8 backwards and became occipito sacral or direct occipito posterior position. As the head of the baby is below the ischial spine, hence vaginal delivery with the help of ventouse or forceps followed by delivery of the head by flexion (unlike extension) occurs. This is known as face-to-pubis delivery.

Highyeild:

The occipitoposterior position is mostly idiopathic. Most common causes: Anthropoid and android pelvis. Most common in nulliparous females. In 90% of cases, normal delivery occurs as the head moves through 3/8th of a circle. Best management: Wait & watch. Android pelvis: DTA common, go for C-section.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A: C section would have been done in case the station would have been above the ischial spine . Hence it is not done. Option B: Manual rotation is not done nowadays. Option D: In this condition, we should not wait and watch as the head will now not be able to deliver spontaneously . Hence this is a wrong statement.

questions.text: A 35-Year-old primigravida female with BMI-34.5kg/m2, presented with abdominal pain at 40 weeks of POG. On PV examination: the fetal head was engaged, and the head of the fetus occupies a position as shown in the figure after rotation from the occipitoposterior position:Even after full dilatation of the cervix since 1 hour, the labor is not progressing. Which of the following is the likely cause of the following presentation?

options.label: B
options.text: Everted ischial spine and parallel side wall of the pelvis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Weak uterine contractions In the given question, the labour is prolonged even after full dilatation and after 1/8 rotation is arrested in transverse diameter known as the deep transverse arrest. Options A, B & D are incorrect.

Highyeild:

Causes of DTA: Faulty pelvic architecture such as prominent ischial spines, flat sacrum and convergent side walls. Deflexion of the head. Laxity of the pelvic floor muscles is a cause.

questions.text: During the delivery of a 25-year-old G2P1, the PV examination shows the following findings: The anterior fontanel is easily felt anteriorly on the left side, the station is -1, membranes intact, and the cervix is 4 cm dilated and 50% effaced. Keeping the PV finding in mind, what should be the per abdomen findings in this patient ? Fetal back is palpated anteriorly Fetal limbs are palpated anteriorly Lower part of the abdomen is flattened after the umbilicus On auscultation the fetal heart sound is heard on the flank Select the correct answer from given below code:-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B, C & D In the given question, the fetal position seems to be occipitoposterior as pointed by: the anterior fontanel is easily felt anteriorly on the left side, so mostly it is right occipitoposterior.

Highyeild:

Per abdomen findings are indicated by the following options: Fetal limbs are palpated anteriorly The lower part of the abdomen is flattened after the umbilicus On auscultation, the fetal heart sound is heard on the flank

Random:

Explanation For other Options:- Option A: If the fetal back is felt anteriorly, then it would have been an occipitoanterior position.

questions.text: Ritgen maneuver is done in the:

options.label: C
options.text: For delivery of legs in breech

options.label: D
options.text: For delivery of head in normal labour

questions.correct_answer: D. For delivery of head in normal labour
questions.explanation:
Solution:

For delivery of head in normal labour

Highyeild:

Ritgen maneuver is done for delivery of the head in normal labour to allow controlled delivery of the head. When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of 5 cm or more , a towel-draped, gloved hand may be used to exert forward pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum just in front of the coccyx. Concurrently, the other hand exerts pressure superiorly against the occiput. This maneuver allows controlled delivery of the head. It also favours neck extension so that the head is delivered with its smallest diameters passing through the introitus and over the perineum.

questions.text: You are examining a 24-Year-old woman with subumbilical flattening. Which of the following statements about the condition is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The neck is extended, the head is deflexed and face presentation can occur

options.label: B
options.text: On per vaginal examination, the anterior fontanelle is felt

options.label: C
options.text: On per vaginal examination, sagittal sutures are felt along the oblique diameter

options.label: D
options.text: Most of the patients will deliver vaginally

questions.correct_answer: A. The neck is extended, the head is deflexed and face presentation can occur
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The neck is extended, the head is deflexed and face presentation can occur Subumbilical flattening due to the absence of the back anteriorly is indicative of occipitoposterior position . All statements are true except Option A , as face-to-pubis delivery might occur in a small percentage of patients which is not equal to face presentation.

Highyeild:

Face presentation occurs in the platypelloid pelvis and cases of anencephaly.

questions.text: You were asked to see a 29-Year-old nulliparous woman in the active second stage of labour, pushing for about an hour and exhausted, asking for a cesarean section. She was induced at 38 weeks for type 1 diabetes and suspected macrosomia. She is contracting 4 in 10 minutes and the CTG is normal. Per abdomen, 0/5th head was palpable and you have confirmed full dilatation, absent membranes, right occipito-posterior (ROP) position with the vertex at spines and descent to +1 during pushing. What is the most appropriate management plan?

options.label: C
options.text: Trial of instrumental delivery in theatre

questions.correct_answer: C. Trial of instrumental delivery in theatre
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trial of instrumental delivery in theatre Trial of instrumental delivery in theatres is the most appropriate plan in this case as the mother is exhausted, with ROP at spines, that is, mid-cavity.

Highyeild:

Operative vaginal births that have a higher risk of failure should be considered for a trial and conducted in a place where immediate recourse to cesarean section can be undertaken. Higher rates of failure are associated with: Maternal body mass index (BMI) over 30 Estimated fetal weight over 4000g or clinically big baby Occipito-posterior position Mid-cavity delivery
